docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN humans eat a lot of sugar, they put on fat. When Alcaligenes eutrophus and some other forms of bacteria indulge in sweets, they fill up with beads of polyester. This biological curiosity could lead to sweeping changes in how plastics and synthetic fibers that incorporate polyesters are produced and used. It is for this reason that Imperial Chemical Industries' agricultural division has spun off a ''plastics-from-bugs'' research and development program, which seemed too small to pursue internally and too promising to forget, into a venture named Marlborough Biopolymers Ltd.
